etymology.description: 牵(牽) (qiān, "to lead") + 牛(牛) (niú, "ox") + 花(花) (huā, "flower") = morning glory, a flower that twines around like it is leading an ox
etymology.interpretation: The name 牵牛花(牽牛花) (qiānniúhuā, "morning glory") evokes the image of the flower's tendrils twining around supports in a manner reminiscent of how a person might lead an ox by a rope. The plant's climbing habit is likened to the motion of guiding an ox.

examples.chinese: 清晨时分(清晨時分)，我在花园里发现了美丽的牵牛花(我在花園裡發現了美麗的牽牛花)。
examples.pinyin: Qīngchén shífèn, wǒ zài huāyuán lǐ fāxiànle měilì de qiānniúhuā.
examples.english: Early in the morning, I discovered beautiful morning glories in the garden.

examples.chinese: 花架上爬满了牵牛花(花架上爬滿了牽牛花)。
examples.english: The trellis is covered with morning glories.

examples.chinese: 黄昏时刻(黃昏時刻)，夕阳映照的牵牛花(夕陽映照的牽牛花)，显得格外动人(顯得格外動人)。
examples.pinyin: Huánghūn shíkè, xīyáng yìngzhào de qiānniúhuā, xiǎnde géwài dòngrén.
examples.english: At dusk, the morning glories illuminated by the setting sun looked exceptionally enchanting.
